fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let I\xrightarrow {F} Top be a diagram in spaces. Then the limit of F has underlying set the limit in Set, topologized by the initial topology: the coarsest topology making the legs \pi _\alpha of the limiting cone continuous.
Explicitly, the initial topology is generated by the subbase \bigcup _{\alpha } \{\pi _\alpha ^{-1}(U): U\subseteq F\alpha \text { open}\}.
Furthermore, the colimit of F has underlying set the colimit in Set, topologized by the final topology: the finest topology making the colegs \iota _\alpha of the colimiting cocone continuous.
Explicitly, a subset U of the colimit is open in the final topology if and only if \iota _\alpha ^{-1}(U) is open for each \alpha .
We give the proof for limits; the proof for colimits is identical. That (X, \pi _\alpha ) is a cone over D is immediate because the initial topology makes the \pi _\alpha continuous.

Let (Z, \tau _\alpha ) be a cone in Top over D. Let f: Z\to X be the canonical map induced by the universal property of the limit in Set. It now remains to show that f is continuous, but this comes precisely from the construction of the initial topology.
A graduate-level textbook that presents basic topology from the perspective of category theory.

Let \coprod X_\alpha be a coproduct of a family of spaces X_\alpha . Then the coproduct topology on \coprod X_\alpha is the final topology with respect to the inclusions X_\beta \xrightarrow {\iota _\beta }\coprod X_\alpha . It thus has the following universal property: a set-function \coprod X_\alpha \xrightarrow {f} Z is continuous if and only if each of the composites X_\beta \xrightarrow {\iota _\beta } \coprod X_\alpha \xrightarrow {f} Z are.
Explicitly, the open subsets of \coprod X_\alpha are exactly the subsets \prod U_\alpha for U_\alpha \subseteq X_\alpha open.

Let \prod X_\alpha be a product of a family of spaces X_\alpha . Then the product topology on \prod X_\alpha is the initial topology with respect to the projections \prod X_\alpha \xrightarrow {\pi _\beta } X_\beta . It thus has the following universal property: a set-function Z\xrightarrow {f} \prod X_\alpha is continuous if and only if each of the composites Z\xrightarrow {f} \prod X_\alpha \xrightarrow {\pi _\beta } X_\beta are.

Explicitly, the product topology is generated by the base \left \{\prod U_\alpha : U_\alpha \subseteq X_\alpha \text { open and } U_\alpha = X_\alpha \text { for all but finitely many }\alpha .\right \}

The point is that the initial topology is generated by the subbase of preimages of open sets under the projections, and we only take finite intersections of these, hence the finite support of the U_\alpha .

Let X/\sim be a quotient of a space X. Then the quotient topology on X/\sim is the final topology with respect to the projection X\xtwoheadrightarrow {\pi } X/\sim . It thus has the following universal property: a set-function X/\sim \,\xrightarrow {f} Z is continuous if and only if the composite X\xrightarrow {\pi }X/\sim \,\xrightarrow {f}Z is.
Explicitly, the open subsets of X/\sim are exactly the subsets U\subseteq X/\sim so that \pi ^{-1}(U) is open in X.

Let Y\subseteq X be a subset of a space X. Then the subspace topology on Y is the initial topology with respect to the inclusion Y\xhookrightarrow {\iota } X. It thus has the following universal property: a set-function Z\xrightarrow {f} Y is continuous if and only if the composite Z\xrightarrow {f}Y\xrightarrow {\iota }X is.
Explicitly, the open subsets of Y are exactly the intersections U\cap Y, where U\subseteq X is open.
Let \mathcal {T} and \mathcal {T}' be topologies on the same underlying set X. Then the following conditions are equivalent:

fr:ul.fr:li: the identity 1_X forms a continuous map (X, \mathcal {T})\to (X, \mathcal {T}').

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We say that \mathcal {T} is coarser than \mathcal {T}' and \mathcal {T}' is finer than \mathcal {T}.
A function f: X\to Y between spaces is continuous if it induces a frame homormorphism via the inverse image: if U\subseteq Y is open, then so is f^{-1}(U).
Set is cocomplete.

By the cocompleteness criterion, it suffices to give coproducts and coequalizers. Coproducts are given by the disjoint union. The coequalizer of functions A\overset {f,g}{\rightrightarrows } B is B / \sim , where \sim is the equivalence relation generated by f(a) \sim g(a) for all a \in A, and / denotes the quotient of sets.
A colimit of a diagram is a universal cocone.

By the definition of universal elements, a colimit of a diagram J\xrightarrow {D} C consists of an object \operatorname *{colim} D\in C and a cocone D \xrightarrow {\lambda } \operatorname *{colim} D which is universal in the sense that it induces, by the Yoneda lemma, a natural isomorphism C(\operatorname *{colim} D, -)\cong \operatorname *{Cocone}_D.

fr:title.text: Set is complete â€º construction of limits in Set

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Set is complete â€º construction of limits in Set

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let J\xrightarrow {D} Set be a small diagram. We define \operatorname *{lim} D = \operatorname *{Cone}_D(*) = \operatorname {Hom}(*, D), where * is the constant functor at the singleton and \operatorname *{Cone} is the cone functor. Note that this is indeed a set, because J is small. An element of this set is a natural transformation *\xrightarrow {\mu } D, which consists of a morphism *\xrightarrow {\mu _j} Dj for each j\in J, hence canonically identifies a J-tuple of elements (x_i\in Dj). The legs of should be maps \operatorname *{lim} D\xrightarrow {\lambda } Dj; we define these by (*\xrightarrow {\mu } D)\xmapsto {\lambda _j} \mu _j(*).

To show that this cone is limiting, let Z\xrightarrow {
u } D be a cone. We need to show that 
u factors uniquely through \lambda . An element z\in Z identifies a map *	o Z, and hence a cone *	o Z\xrightarrow {
u } D, which is thus an element t(z)\in \operatorname *{lim} D. Now \lambda _j(t(z)) = (
u z)_j = 
u _j(z), and so 
u = \lambda t, as desired. It remains to show uniqueness, but any function Z\xrightarrow {u} \operatorname *{lim} D factoring 
u must satisfy u(z)_j = \lambda _j(u(z)) = 
u _j(z) = (
u z)_j = t(z)_j, so we are done.
A commutatitive diagram in a category C is a functor J\xrightarrow {D} C. The domain J is called the indexing category or the shape of the diagram.
A limit of a diagram is a universal cone.

By the definition of universal elements, a limit of a diagram J\xrightarrow {D} C consists of an object \operatorname *{lim} D\in C and a cone \operatorname *{lim} D\xrightarrow {\lambda } D which is universal in the sense that it induces, by the Yoneda lemma, a natural isomorphism C(-, \operatorname *{lim} D)\cong \operatorname *{Cone}_D.
The category of topological spaces Top is the category whose objects are topological spaces and whose morphisms are continuous functions.
